Line.Text: Good morning, Michael.
Good morning once again.
And to you, Jackie. Shame it’ll be my last one here.
You bet it is! After all, it’s the day I finally get done with this thing.
You keep saying that. I don’t think any of them were good.
Are you excited to meet the big boss?
I feel the same way. Are you excited to meet the big boss?
Yeah, I’m sure you can barely hold a triumphant hooray. How do you feel about meeting the big boss? Interested?
Well, you are certainly entitled to your opinion. All I can say is that we tried our best. How do you feel about meeting the big boss? Interested?
I guess so. It should be educating to meet a businessman of such caliber.
Nah, he’s probably an ass. All the quota of nice people in this story was already used up on you.
I don’t really have any expectations.
I think you can count on that.
Aw, what a sweet thing to say.
You’ve earned it. I really enjoyed our time together these past days.
It wasn’t such a big quota to begin with, mind you. One might even call it tiny.
Thank you. And allow me to say that it’s mutual.
Yeah, I think I’ll ignore that part and concentrate on the compliment.
That’s probably wise.
Any tips on the final problem?
Are we meeting somewhere around here?
Well, it might be weird and sudden and surprising, but I’m sure you’re pretty much used to it at this point.

Sure, on this very floor. See the passage to my left?[pause] What you need to do is walk through it and just continue down the corridor until you see an imposing-looking door. There’ll be a nameplate attached nearby, stating that it’s the office of the CEO, such and such… pretty hard to miss.
Aren’t you going with me?

No, the boss left specific instructions to make you approach him alone. I’m pretty much on holiday today.[pause] The first one in many months of crunch, actually… yeah, that’ll be a forgotten feeling.
Will we meet again?
In general? I think it’s entirely up to you. But not during this project, no. My work here, wordy and protracted as it was, is done now.
So it’s kind of a goodbye time, eh?
Yep. It’s that part of the story where we say how mere four days of one adventure have changed our lives forever and then tearfully fall into each other’s embrace.
I don’t think it’s that kind of story.
I thought you said this was a job, not an adventure.
Nooooooo thank you.
And here I was, ready to confess my feelings in a dignified, trope-respecting way.

Yeah, you’re right, of course. But at least it’s a story where I end up telling a bad joke.[pause] I usually don’t tell my worst jokes to people unless I feel really comfortable around them… and that joke was damn awful. So that’s something, right?

You know, it was much more adventurous that I ever expected. I even get to tell a bad joke.[pause] I usually don’t tell my worst jokes to people unless I feel really comfortable around them… and that joke was damn awful. So that’s something, right?

Relax, it’s just a joke. But hey, you know what?[pause] I usually don’t tell my worst jokes to people unless I feel really comfortable around them… and that joke was damn awful. So that’s something, right?

Yeah, and I just went and made a horrible joke. Totally ruined the moment.[pause] But you know what? I usually don’t tell my worst jokes to people unless I feel really comfortable around them… and that joke was damn awful. So that’s something, right?
Yeah… that’s something.
Good thing the cells renewal is around, too. It could’ve been much worse if it wasn’t. You could’ve been stuck with a 61-year-old grandma as your guide.
Now you’re just messing around.
That’s pure conjecture.
Still, just imagine: old toothless Jackie sitting in a rickety chair, cursing her decrepit aching bones, screaming at kids to get off the grass or something.
You’re overdramatizing. Sixty one is not nearly as old.
Not a very pleasant sight, to be sure.
The lawn. If you’re looking for an old American idiom, it’s “get off my lawn.”
I thought you weren’t into this whole stereotyping thing.

Perhaps you’re right. Everyone is different, of course. I should’ve found out what kind of an old lady I am by now; only it didn’t happen.[pause] And it feels… weird. Even years down the road, it feels so very weird…[clear]I… I hope I played my part as well as I could. I hope you can see this future like I try to see it myself.[pause] It’s not perfect by any means, but it’s not bad either. It’s neither fair nor unfair, neither fixed nor broken, neither random nor predetermined, neither crazy nor sane – it’s all of these things at the same time.

Exactly. But it didn’t happen to me. Millennia of history tell me that it should, but it didn’t.[pause] And it feels… weird. Even years down the road, it feels so very weird…[clear]I… I hope I played my part as well as I could. I hope you can see this future like I try to see it myself.[pause] It’s not perfect by any means, but it’s not bad either. It’s neither fair nor unfair, neither fixed nor broken, neither random nor predetermined, neither crazy nor sane – it’s all of these things at the same time.

See? I’m completely uneducated on what it means to be an old person. I should’ve been an old person myself by now, only it didn’t happen.[pause] And it feels… weird. Even years down the road, it feels so very weird…[clear]I… I hope I played my part as well as I could. I hope you can see this future like I try to see it myself.[pause] It’s not perfect by any means, but it’s not bad either. It’s neither fair nor unfair, neither fixed nor broken, neither random nor predetermined, neither crazy nor sane – it’s all of these things at the same time.

I know, right? Definitely not my best moment. I’m so uneducated on what it means to be an old person, it’s embarrassing. I should’ve been an old person myself by now, only it didn’t happen.[pause] And it feels… weird. Even years down the road, it feels so very weird…[clear]I… I hope I played my part as well as I could. I hope you can see this future like I try to see it myself.[pause] It’s not perfect by any means, but it’s not bad either. It’s neither fair nor unfair, neither fixed nor broken, neither random nor predetermined, neither crazy nor sane – it’s all of these things at the same time.
That’s a good way to look at the world.
I think you’ve managed to carry that across.
I disagree, but I understand your point.

I appreciate you saying that. Honestly, I don’t want to shove my views down anyone’s throat; that would be a horrible thing to do. I just think it’s the truth, and I believe it with all my heart.[clear]And who knows, maybe even that will change. Maybe one day our world will become an honest trouble-free paradise, or turn into a living post-apocalyptic hell, or succumb to any other simple, convenient narrative…[pause] but until then, this is the real thing. The best thing we’ve managed to build. Our beautiful, complicated mess.[clear]And Michael? Thank you. Thank you for everything you’ve done. I wish you all the luck in this world of 2048, or that world of 2018, or any other world you might find yourself in. Be well.
You too, Jackie. You too.
Thanks, I’ll try.
